original_title: Sri Lanka’s mid day shares edge up
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s shares edge up in mid day trade for the seventh straight session, after foreign reports suggested that the International Monetary Fund (IMF) is likely to lend Sri Lanka the long awaited 2.9 billion dollar loan without debt restructuring assurances from China.
All Share Price Index (ASPI) was up 0.35 percent or 31.94 points to 9,287.93, while the most liquid share S&P SL20 was up 0.39 percent or 10.90 points to 2,835.
Cash dividends have been declared by Sampath Bank and DFCC Bank, which has prompted some confidence in the banking sector shares seeing stability and economic improvement.
“Cash dividends come as an indication of normalisation,” said an analyst.
Investors are on a wait and see approach, anticipating and speculating rate cuts by the Monetary Policy Review which has been scheduled for March 02.
The market generated a turnover of 1.4 billion rupees at 12oo hours.
Top gainers during mid day trade were Sampath Bank, Commerical Bank and Ceylon Tobacco Company. (Colombo/Feb24/2023)
